R Markdown is a powerful tool that combines text, R code, and results in the same document, and LaTex is a typesetting system commonly used in academia for its mathematical notation capabilities. When you bring these two together, you get a seamless workflow for scientific writing. This guide will walk you through how to write math formulas in R Markdown using LaTex.

# Inline and Displayed Math

There are two ways you can write math in R Markdown:inline and displayed.

## Inline Math

Inline math is when you want to Include a mathematical symbol or a short formula within a sentence. To write inline math, you can enclose your LaTex code with dollar signs ('`$`').

For instance, writing '`$a^2 + b^2 = b^2$`' in your R Markdown file will render as $a^2 + b^2 = c^2$ in your output document.

## Displayed Math

Displayed math is when you want to display a standalone equation. This is typically done for long formulas or when you want to draw attention to the equation. To write displayed math, you can enclose your LaTex code with double dollar signs('`$$`').

For instance, writing

``` latex
$$
a^2 = b^2 + c^2 \\
a = 5, b = 4, c = 3
$$
```

in your R Markdown file will render as: $$
\begin{aligned}
a^2=b^2+c^2 \\ 
a=5, b=4, c=3
\end{aligned}
$$ in your output document.

## Four Arithmetic Operation

| Symbolic Name       | Code    | Example     |
|---------------------|---------|-------------|
| plus sign           | \+      | a+b         |
| minus sign          | --      | a-b         |
| plus and mins sign  | \\pm    | a \\pm b    |
| mins and plus sign  | \\mp    | a \\mp b    |
| times sign          | \\times | a \\times b |
| asterisk sign       | --      | a-b         |
| dot sign            | \\cdot  | a \\cdot b  |
| division sign       | \\div   | a \\div b   |
| bevel division sign | /       | a / b       |

``` latex
$$
BasicOperations: a+b, a-b, a*b, a \ast b, a/b\\
ExtendedOperations: a\pm b, a \mp b, a \times b, a \cdot b, a \div b
$$
```

$$
\begin{aligned}
basic operations: a+b, a-b, a*b, a \ast b, a/b\\
Extended Operations: a\pm b, a \mp b, a \times b, a \cdot b, a \div b
\end{aligned}
$$

## Brackets

1\. Parentheses and square brackets\
Use original `()` and `[]`, such as `(2+3)*[4+4]`.

2\. Curly braces\
Since curly braces `{}` are used for grouping, you need to use `\{ and \}` to represent curly braces, or you can use `\lbrace` and `\rbrace` to represent them. Such as `\{a*b\}` or `\lbrace a*b \rbrace`

3\. Angle brackets\
Use `\langle` and `\rangle` to represent left angle brackets and right angle brackets. Such as `\langle x \rangle`.

4\. Rounding up and rounding down\
Use `\lceil` and `\rceil` to represent rounding up, such as `\lceil x \rceil`. Use `\lfloor` and `\rfloor` to represent rounding down, such as `\lfloor x \rfloor`.

``` latex
$$
Parentheses: (2+3) \\
Square Brackets: [4+4] \\
Curly Braces: \{a*b\}*\lbrace c+d \rbrace \\
Angle Brackets: \langle x \rangle \\
RoundingUp: \lceil x \rceil \\
RoundingDown: \lfloor x \rfloor
$$
```

$$
\begin{aligned}
Parentheses: (2+3) \\
Square Brackets: [4+4] \\
Curly Braces: \{a*b\}*\lbrace c+d \rbrace \\
Angle Brackets: \langle x \rangle \\
RoundingUp: \lceil x \rceil \\
RoundingDown: \lfloor x \rfloor
\end{aligned}
$$

## Superscript, Subscript, Top

Use `^` for superscript and `_` for subscript. For example, `x_i^2`.

By default, superscripts and subscripts only apply to the next group. A group is a single character or a content wapped with `{..}`. Compared with 10^10, it is different from 10^{10}. Use curly braces to eliminate ambiguity. For example, x^5^6 is wrong syntax and needs to be written as {x^5}^6 or x^{5^6}.

```latex
$$
x_i^2 \\
Differences: 10^10 \ and 10^{10} \\
Differences: {x^5}^6 and x^{5^6}
$$
```


$$
\begin{aligned}
x_i^2 \\
Differences: 10^10 \ and\ 10^{10} \\
Differences: {x^5}^6 \ and\ x^{5^6}
\end{aligned}
$$
